synonymy: When two or more species that were previously thought to be distinct and unique are found to share a common origin or identity, often revealing a complex history of misidentification, resulting in a reclassification of their status and relationships.

The practice of reconciling previously distinct identities between organisms by uncovering their underlying relationships, often revealing that what was thought to be multiple species are, in fact, variations of the same species.

When two distinct entities, often referred to by different names, are actually different expressions of the same underlying reality, such as a species, but share a common origin and characteristics, resulting in a reevaluation of their individual identities and a broader understanding of their distribution and prevalence.

The act of reclassification or revision of a previously identified species, prompted by the discovery of novel evidence, which reveals that it is actually a variation or alias of an already known and described species.

The process of reclassifying a previously recognized species or entity within a scientific classification system, often as a result of new evidence or observations that reveal a more accurate relationship or identity, which may lead to a revised understanding of the distribution, prevalence, or range of certain species.
synidotea: A crustacean species that has traversed vast distances, often unintentionally, through human activity, and has adapted to inhabit diverse marine and estuarine environments, its global spread masked by previous misidentifications and synonymies.
A species that, through its global dispersion, has the propensity to blur the lines between its native and introduced ranges, necessitating the reevaluation of geographical and taxonomic boundaries.

A group of crustaceans characterized by their invasive tendencies, ability to adapt to various aquatic environments, and propensity to be misidentified as distinct species due to their widespread distribution and ability to evolve in response to human activities.

A cosmopolitan crustacean genus that has exploited human maritime activities to spread its populations across the globe, often under the guise of misidentified species, leading to an underestimated prevalence of marine and estuarine introductions.

A type of crustacean that has a remarkable ability to traverse the globe, often unwittingly carried by humans, and has a propensity to adapt to new environments, leading to unexpected ecological impacts and revisions in its species classification.
isopods: Small, often overlooked, crustaceans that have evolved to thrive in a wide range of aquatic environments, with some species unexpectedly colonizing new areas through human activity, demonstrating their remarkable ability to adapt and thrive in unfamiliar settings.

Tiny, often-overlooked crustaceans that have mastered the art of hitchhiking on ships and continents, quietly colonizing new waters with alarming frequency and causing scientists to reevaluate their understanding of global introductions.

A type of crustacean characterized by their ability to hitchhike on global transportation networks, often going unnoticed until they establish widespread populations, redefining the ecological landscape and forcing scientists to reevaluate their understanding of introductions.

Crustaceans with a segmented body, typically small to medium-sized, often found in aquatic environments, and capable of hitchhiking onto ships, leading to widespread geographic distribution and mistaken identities among scientists.

Crustaceans with a unique body plan, often referred to as "pill bugs" or "rolly pollies," that have a global presence and can infiltrate new environments through human activities, showcasing their ability to thrive in diverse aquatic and terrestrial settings.
